articles.title: Johnson & Johnson to Split Off Orthopedics Business
articles.summary: Johnson & Johnson announced plans to separate its artificial hip and knee replacement division, DePuy Synthes, into a stand-alone company within 18 to 24 months. This strategic move aims to enable J&J to focus on higher-growth businesses. The orthopedics unit was chosen for separation due to its lower growth rate and profit margins compared to other medical-device segments.

articles.title: Johnson & Johnson to Split Off Orthopedics Business
articles.summary: Johnson & Johnson announced plans to separate its artificial hip and knee business, currently branded as DePuy Synthes, into a stand-alone company within 18 to 24 months. This strategic move aims to allow J&J to focus on faster-growing business segments, as the orthopedics division has experienced lower growth and margins compared to other medical-device units. This separation is part of J&J's ongoing efforts to streamline its operations.

articles.title: Johnson & Johnson to Split Off Orthopedics Business

This strategic move aims to allow J&J to focus on faster-growing segments, as the orthopedics division exhibits lower growth and margins compared to other medical-device units. This separation is part of the healthcare giant's ongoing efforts to streamline its operations.

articles.title: Johnson & Johnson to Split Off Orthopedics Business
articles.summary: Johnson & Johnson announced plans to spin off its artificial hip and knee replacement division into a new stand-alone company called DePuy Synthes within 18 to 24 months. This move is part of J&J's strategy to streamline its operations and focus on faster-growing businesses. The orthopedics unit is being separated due to its lower growth and margins compared to other medical-device segments like heart devices, surgical products, and vision care.

This move aims to allow J&J to focus on higher-growth and higher-margin businesses within its medical-device unit. articles.title: J&Jâ€™s Shockwave reports positive IVL data for below-the-knee lesions, CLTI
articles.summary: Johnson & Johnson MedTech's Shockwave Medical announced positive one-year results from its DISRUPT BTK II study, evaluating the Shockwave peripheral IVL system for calcified lesions below-the-knee, especially in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI). The study demonstrated symptom relief, limb salvage, and improved quality of life, with high rates of freedom from major amputation and clinically driven revascularization. These findings highlight the critical role of IVL in wound healing and limb preservation for complex arterial disease patients.

articles.title: Johnson & Johnson $JNJ Shares Bought by Bank of New York Mellon Corp
articles.summary: Bank of New York Mellon Corp increased its stake in Johnson & Johnson (NYSE:JNJ) by 2.7% in Q2, making JNJ its 20th biggest position. Other institutional investors also adjusted their holdings. The article details recent analyst ratings, reflecting a "Moderate Buy" consensus, insider selling by EVP Jennifer L. Taubert, and financial performance data for Johnson & Johnson.

articles.title: Corporation building Warren plant to buy maker of Tylenol
articles.summary: Kimberly-Clark, currently establishing an $800 million plant in Warren, announced plans to acquire Kenvue, the company behind Tylenol, Listerine, and Neutrogena. This acquisition will merge two large American companies, creating a health and wellness powerhouse with an estimated yearly revenue of $32 billion and featuring ten iconic brands each generating over a billion dollars in sales. The deal, valued at approximately $48.7 billion, is expected to finalize in the second half of 2026, pending shareholder and regulatory approvals.

articles.title: Tylenol Maker Kenvue Acquired For Billions
articles.summary: Kimberly-Clark has announced its acquisition of Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol, in a cash and stock deal valued at $48.7 billion. This acquisition brings brands like Aveeno and Listerine under Kimberly-Clark, while Kenvue is also embroiled in lawsuits regarding alleged links between Tylenol and autism, claims which Kenvue strongly disputes.

articles.title: Tylenol maker Kenvue misses sales estimates amid Kimberly-Clark's $48.7-billion deal
articles.summary: Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol, missed Wall Street estimates for third-quarter sales, while simultaneously announcing its acquisition by Kimberly-Clark for approximately $48.7 billion. The company has faced challenges, including an 11% decline in Tylenol sales following controversial comments linking the drug to autism, and a 3.5% decrease in overall net sales to $3.76 billion. Kenvue also named Kirk Perry as its new permanent CEO and reiterated its 2025 adjusted profit outlook.

articles.title: Corporation building Warren plant to buy maker of Tylenol
articles.summary: Kimberly-Clark, which is building an $800 million manufacturing facility in Warren, plans to acquire Kenvue, the maker of Tylenol, Listerine, and Neutrogena. This deal, valued at approximately $48.7 billion, will merge two large consumer health companies, creating a powerhouse with an estimated yearly revenue of $32 billion and nine iconic billion-dollar brands. The acquisition aims to combine their complementary product lines and market strengths, with completion expected in the second half of 2026.
